section.name: Expressed information and ideas to others

values.desc: No evidence
Ineffectively
Adequately
Effectively

values.name: a
values.desc: Spoke clearly and loudly enough for all team members to hear

values.name: b
values.desc: Used a tone that invited other people to respond

values.name: c
values.desc: Language/terminology was suitable for the listeners and context

values.name: d
values.desc: Duration of speaking was effective for the listeners

values.name: e
values.desc: The level of detail was appropriate to convey the necessary information
Speak audibly and clearly to your team members so everyone can hear you.
Use a tone of voice that is friendly and inviting.
Carefully choose your words to align with the level of the material, using phrases and sentences that are comprehensible
Choose language that doesn't make others feel uncomfortable; don't make the setting uninviting.
Speak for a length of time that allows frequent back and forth conversation.

section.name: Paid attention to the speaker as information and ideas were communicated

values.desc: No evidence
Rarely
Sometimes
Consistently

values.name: a
values.desc: Patiently listened without interrupting the speaker

values.name: b
values.desc: Referenced others' ideas to indicate listening and understanding
Allow team members to finish their thoughts.
Turn to face the team member that is speaking and make eye contact.
Indicate if you can't hear someone's spoken words.
Restate or write down what the previous speaker said to indicate that you were listening and understood their idea.
Give credit and acknowledge people by name.

section.name: Replied or reacted to the communicated information and ideas

values.desc: No evidence
Rarely
Sometimes
Consistently

values.name: a
values.desc: Acknowledged other members for their ideas or contributions

values.name: b
values.desc: Rephrased or referred to what other group members have said

values.name: c
values.desc: Asked other group members to further explain a concept

values.name: d
values.desc: Elaborated or extended on someone else's idea(s)
Let team members know when they make a productive contribution (this promotes positive and inclusive communication).
State what others have said in your own words to confirm understanding.
Ask a follow-up question or ask for clarification.
Reference what others have said when you build on their ideas.
Offer an alternative to what a team member said.

section.name: Used productive body language while speaking, listening, and responding to promote communication.

values.desc: No evidence
Rarely
Sometimes
Consistently

values.name: a
values.desc: Used body language to indicate they were listening

values.name: b
values.desc: Give positive feedback/affirmation to group members while they speak

values.name: c
values.desc: Avoided behaviors that others have indicated are distracting

values.name: d
values.desc: Avoid engaging in activities that divert you from the task

values.name: e
values.desc: Turned their attention to the speaker when they were speaking
Face your group members and make eye contact.
Use active-listening body language (nodding, leaning forward, following along with the task)
Consider whether your behavior(s) may be distracting to others.
Put away things that distract you or others.
